course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Business Programming in R
course.description: This course provides an introduction to business programming using R. Students will learn the programming concepts and syntax of R and develop R scripts for business applications. This course will cover practical issues for programming in R and provide working examples of emerging business applications, including Web crawling, text analytics, social network analysis, online advertising, and implementations of data mining algorithms.
course.prerequisites: (ISOM 3230 OR ISOM 3320 OR ISOM 3400) AND ISOM 3360

reviews.author: Meowlo
reviews.title: Good programming course for business analytics
reviews.comment_content:
Course Goals and Objectives
• Understand generic programming language concepts in R
• Know how to obtain data from a variety of sources and tidy data for downstream analysis tasks
with R
• Understand the basic principles of constructing data graphics and be familiarized with the plotting
systems and visualization features in R
• Understand how to write R scripts and use various R packages for business applications
• Use R Markdown to write reports that include R code and the code’s automatically-generated output

Before midterm, Jia Jia will teach you some simple programming stuff like data type, flow controls, functions, loops... Some additional stuff would be scoping rules, environments, and the apply family.

After midterm, the focuses are on data visualization with ggplot and some classes on text analytics.

This course is useful especially when you know that in the future your boss will only look at how you tell the story of data, which means data visualization is important. Also, web scrapping skills and text analytics techniques are useful skills.

Some people maybe wonder whether they should the R or Python. To be honest, I think python would be better but since the python course ISOM3400 is designed for beginners, it might not carry everything necessary for data analysis purpose. So I will recommend taking R if you want to further expand your knowledge in the data analysis aspect.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It might be a little bit hard to understand Jia Jia's English... To understand what he says, first you need to know what he gonna say... Like some terms if you haven't heard of that before, you can hardly know he is referring to that.

For the course, he tries to elaborate a lot on the fundamentals of programming as he knows most IS students don't quite know how to code. This would be friendly to most of the students but maybe just not me.

Initially, most students attended the class. Yet, as there are no final exam, only me and another student attended class after midterm exam.

Charles is helpful during the lab session, you can essentially ask him anything and since the class size is quite small, it's quite chill.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade breakdown is as follows:
• Lab participation: 10%
• Homework (4): 40%
• Midterm quiz: 25%
• Final project: 25% (10% out of 25% will be based on your team-mates’ assessment of your
contribution)

The grade is pretty good. Since there is no final exam, midterm will be the major factor determining your grade. Other components should share similar scores. I score 92/100 in midterm and end up getting A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
Low workload. 4 homeworks which are just like the lab materials and you don't really need to look at additional information to finish the homework. Though the lab could be hard sometimes and most of the students have to consult the TA Charles to finish the lab including me. So, get a reliable friend or get to be friend with Charles.

The project is just a web-scrapping and text analytics project which you should be able to handle with the lecture notes.

reviews.author: Aaron W
reviews.title: Easy course if you have programming experience
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers topics ranging from the basics syntax of R, to data visualization (ggplot), web scraping (RSelinium), and a bit of textual analysis.

The notes and lecture structure were quite comprehensive, and I liked the format of using RMarkdown in place of lecture slides, as it made it a lot more interactive, as you can run the code yourself.

The two assignments were about data manipulation and visualization, with the final project being a web scraping project (sentimental analysis of movie reviews on imbd).
reviews.comment_teaching: The course was taught by one of the PhD students, QIAN, Bingjie, and she was quite good as she was very clear and approachable. Even though I didn't go to the classes (since I was doing an internship), I didn't have any trouble learning the content from the lecture videos. She was also very happy to answer any questions we had (both during lecture time and out).
reviews.comment_grading:
There was no attendance, and the in-class exercises and labs were due the next day at noon.  We had around two weeks each for the assignments and project.

Labs and in-class exercises
A. In-class Exercises (13) 20%
B. Lab Exercises (13) 20%
C. Assignments (2) 30%
D. Final Project 30%

Me: Maxed
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Even though it was 3hr lectures + 1hr labs Mon, Wed, and Fri, if you are confident in your programming skills, the workload is very light, as the in-class and lab exercises can be done just by looking at/copying from the lecture videos and the assignments and project are only a few hours of work. I was able to easily handle it while doing a full-time internship.

If you aren't confident in your programming skills, then this course might take a lot of your time since it is very rushed during the summer semester.

Also, the prerequisites can be waived (I haven't actually taken any of them).

reviews.author: 123gg
reviews.title: BAD GRADE course for business school students
reviews.comment_content: If you don't care about grades and wanted to learn R in a short period of time, this is a good course with rich content !
reviews.comment_teaching: The lectures are all changed to zoom consultation session where you can ask the prof questions regarding in class ex. His accent is a bit hard to understand but I heard his teaching this semester is much better than his previous semesters.
reviews.comment_grading:
If you're not from business school, please ignore the following comments (and why the hell are you taking a programming course offered by business school !)

BAD GRADE!
Also, who the hell says that winter semester is good grade ==
My speculation is that most people taking this course are not from business school and have taken advance comp courses, hence the bad grade for normal business school students like me. Might also be harsh absolute grading but regardless, it's just a bad grade course.

This is the worst grade programming course offered in business school that I have taken. I have taken ISOM 3400 and ISOM 3360 before and got A (as reference), but I got B+ in this course.
reviews.comment_workload: In-class exercise every lesson (around 9), 2 assignments, and take home exam (24 hours) The workload is ok if you have prior programming experience. Don't take this course if you have no programming experience, since the prof expects everyone to have a good programming foundation.
